Award.AbstractNarration:
Estela Blaisten-Barojas and Iosif Vaisman of George Mason University are supported by the NSF Division of Chemistry under the Cyberinfrastructure and Research Facilities Program. This project will develop intelligent data mining tools and materials design strategies using the National Institute for Standards and Technology crystallographic and materials property data sources as an initial testbed. This cyber-intelligent connection of well-validated experimental data will lead to correlations and patterns that can be fed back to the data source with the following objectives: 1) to develop a rational cyber-design for determining the nature and types of data equivalencies in the structural chemical information of inorganic materials; 2) to open a visual portal enhancing the use of intelligently organized correlations of structural chemical data for predicting new materials; 3) to develop a Web-based learning system for educational purposes; 4) to enhance and improve accessibility and query tools; and 5) to replace legacy point-to-point query systems in the chemical sciences by a system conveying global validated correlations across databases.

Several communities in the chemical sciences will benefit from this Web-based intelligent system to query databases: solid-state synthetic experimentalists, theoretical chemical modelers and simulators, chemical educators, and instrument builders. In addition, this cyber-system will be deployed and tested in several introductory chemistry courses. Additional educational activities will include: 1) a battery of projects to be developed by chemistry undergraduates and incorporated into the intelligent system in order to search and discover structural knowledge of inorganic materials; and 2) the organization of groups of graduate students presenting their graduate projects (containing pieces of the Web-based system) in courses of the two summer workshops for undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The central theme of the project was the development of machine learning algorithms and models for the structural analysis of inorganic crystals based on data stored in databases. During this project we developed machine learning models that allow to classify zeolite crystals according to their framework type. Zeolites are porous crystalline materials with highly regular framework structures consisting of molecular-sized pores and channels. The characteristic framework type of a zeolite is conventionally defined by combining information on its coordination sequences, vertex symbols, tiling, and transitivity information. Our categorization model, the Zeolite Structure Predictor (ZSP), is based on the Random ForestTM algorithm and uses a nine-dimensional feature vector including topological descriptors obtained by computational geometry techniques, together with selected physical and chemical properties of zeolite crystals. Trained on the crystallographic structures of real zeolites collected into the Inorganic Crystal Structure Database (ICSD), our model predicts the framework types of zeolite crystals with 98% accuracy. Additionally, we have demonstrated that zeolite structural properties may be clustered according to topological descriptors into four broader categories. The latter are very useful for fast screening of newly synthesized zeolite crystals. In parallel, we developed further the Adaptive Tempering Monte Carlo (ATMC) method with the purpose of analyzing the structure of numerically created chemical materials with emphasis on amorphous systems such as polymers, nanostructures, glasses, and cluster-assembled solids. The computational tasks were heavy and two satellite Teragrid-XSEDE grants were used extensively.

Through supplemental funding, awarded within the 2010-NSF competition Computing in the Cloud, extensive software was adapted and ported to the Microsoft Windows Azure cloud platform. This solicitation was specific for developing scientific applications for cloud computing and was coupled with the NSF-Microsoft Research MOU that added the resources on the Microsoft public cloud to every award. We developed a cloud-based computing system in the Windows Azure cloud that allows users to use the ZSP model through a Web browser. This automated system permits a user to calculate the feature vector used by ZSP and classify the structure of newly synthesized zeolites. The software workflow is named "SAMPCloud" and integrates executables in Fortran and Python for number crunching with WEKA for machine learning and Jmol for Web-based atomistic visualization in an interactive compute system accessed through the Web. SAMPCloud is robust, easy to use, and open source (download available from SourceForge). Communities of scientists, engineers, and students knowledgeable in Windows-based computing will find this new workflow attractive and easy to be implemented in scientific scenarios in which the developer needs to combine heterogeneous software components.

The research has given rise to nine publications on zeolite structure, six ATMC publications and its applications on polypyrroles, five publications on nanostructures, and one cloud software publication. The cloud-based software is open source and gave rise to one publication. Five doctoral students were advised by the PIs and graduated with their PhD (one female and one African American). Two other doctoral students are in the pipeline. Two postdoctoral associates were trained. They presented work in eleven conferences, including the national ACS meetings and APS March meetings. Four international visitors have been associated with this project (one female).
